Arcade Fire this is their fifth studio

funeral genre-defining record a high
point for indie rock tons of epic
lavishly arranged songs on this thing
packed with passionate vocals the record
also in my opinion has a flawless flow
and then the band followed that up a few

Bible a record that featured a lot of
religious themes heavenly musical highs
dark depressing lows and then the band's
third record I also enjoyed the suburbs
it was kind of like a little baby in a

most direct album yet in my opinion as

reflector several years ago the album
boasted production from LCD
Soundsystem's James Murphy and featured
the band's most danceable material yet
pulling influence directly from the
worlds of disco and new wave now
personally in my opinion this is where
the band in their discography had first
faltered easily the most inconsistent
Arcade Fire album so far I thought it

oh here we go again I don't want more of

Age I kind of get the sense that the

and beautiful that I don't know it's
it's almost like they're paying tribute

I think the maximal materialistic
mentality of the modern age is an
